Hi -
last week (on Wednesday, to be precise), I wrote:

> The reason I jumped to the mailing list is that 2 of us want to write a
> doclet *a few hours from now*, and we want to do TDD ... maybe someone
here
> is kind enough to shoot a quick answer at me ...]

- and we did it! (we had to - it's a really needed tool)

And I'm not satisfied with the result and the TDD-ing we did ... But before
I share my questions and concerns, I'd like to see how TDDing our assignment
would or should really work. For this, 

>>>>> I invite you to also implement the tool we had to write. <<<<<

For this, I have put a sort of spec on my website at
http://www.haraldmmueller.de/swe_tdd1.html. 

It took us 2 hours 16 minutes end-to-end (including the shaky acceptance
test on the website), and we were as unknowing about doclets as one can be -
so you have every chance to do the same thing in an hour or so.

Everyone sending me (or posting) a "TDD solution" (including unit tests)
will get in return our code ... if you like to criticize others' code, that
should really be an incentive ;-)

When I have two working solutions, I'll post - if I may - our code (maybe on
the refactoring mailing list? don't know where it suites better) so that you
can tear it apart.

Is this a deal ;-) ?


JB (Joe - now I know it!) Rainsberger found time to answer - I'll only
comment on one part:

>Now fortunately, RootDoc is an interface, so we ought to be able to mock 
>it, or provide a simple implementation of it, to pass in to the method 
>start(), which I /assume/ you're trying to test-drive.

"Yes, but ..." (my children's answer to almost everything ...): If you look
at the documentation of RootDoc and related interfaces - i.e., the javadoc
API -, it's not too small. Should I really mock this? I cannot see that I'll
then create a software that will run with the real javadoc API - I will
misinterpret the Javadoc and implement mocks that do what I think they
should do, not what the real thing does.
So, I need learning tests for RootDoc etc. anyway, so why not write the
doclet so that *is* the learning test object?
But when I find time, I'll try also the mock approach - otherwise, I'll
never lose my prejudice about it; and post the result without any feeling of
guilt.

Ok - now I'm waiting for contributions ...

Regards
Harald M. Mueller
